This dissatisfaction has increased over the years, as shown in the graph [![{Public dissatisfaction with the state of the nation is higher than at any point in the past year, and it has increased 9 percentage points since September (when 61% of adults said they were dissatisfied).}](image1)]. The graph also indicates that satisfaction levels have been consistently low among Democrats during Trump's presidency, with no more than 16% expressing satisfaction [![{modestly since September (from 14%), no more than 16% of Democrats have expressed satisfaction with the way things are going in the country at any point during Trump’s presidency.}](image1)]. In contrast, Republican satisfaction has seen a drop, with 47% of Republicans and Republican leaners now saying they are dissatisfied, down from 59% in September [![{Today, as many Republicans and Republican leaners say they are dissatisfied with the way things are going in the country as say they are satisfied (47% each). This is a 12-percentage-point drop in satisfaction from September (when 59% of Republicans said they were satisfied and 35% were dissatisfied), and the lowest GOP satisfaction rating since late 2017.}](image1)]. These trends highlight the deep partisan divisions in public opinion regarding both Wall Street's impact and overall national satisfaction.

From 1990 to 2019, public satisfaction levels have shown a significant decline, as illustrated in image2. In conclusion, public satisfaction levels have significantly decreased from 1990 to 2019, with a notable drop among Republicans and consistently low satisfaction among Democrats. This trend has contributed to a clear partisan divide on views of Wall Street's impact on the economy, with Republicans generally more positive about Wall Street's role in the economy than Democrats.

The perspectives on the reasons for rising COVID-19 cases and the lifting of restrictions vary significantly across political affiliations. Regarding the lifting of restrictions, 93% of liberal Democrats and 88% of conservative and moderate Democrats are concerned that restrictions have been lifted too quickly [1][2]. On the other hand, 53% of Republicans are more concerned that restrictions have not been lifted quickly enough, with 60% of conservative Republicans expressing this concern [8].

The views on the causes of increased COVID-19 cases and opinions on lifting restrictions among different political groups show a clear partisan divide. According to the text, Democrats overwhelmingly attribute the rise in coronavirus cases primarily to more infections, not just more testing [7]. In contrast, a majority of Republicans say the primary reason is because more people are being tested [9]. This is reflected in the image showing that 80% of Democrats believe there are more new infections, not just more tests, while only 36% of Republicans hold this view [![{conclusion}](image5)].

Furthermore, Democrats are more likely than Republicans to say most of these factors are major reasons the outbreak has continued. The widest partisan differences are on whether the federal government response is inadequate – 82% of Democrats view this as a major reason the outbreak has continued, compared with 21% of Republicans – and lifting COVID-19 restrictions too quickly (82% of Democrats, 31% of Republicans) [6]. The image supports this by showing that 82% of Democrats believe restrictions have been lifted too quickly in some places, while only 31% of Republicans agree [![{conclusion}](image3)].

In terms of lifting restrictions, the image shows that 90% of liberal Democrats are more concerned that state governments have been lifting restrictions too quickly, compared to 37% of conservative Republicans [![{conclusion}](image4)]. This indicates a significant difference in opinion on lifting restrictions between liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans.

In conclusion, Democrats are more likely to attribute the rise in COVID-19 cases to more infections and are more concerned about lifting restrictions too quickly, while Republicans are more likely to attribute the rise in cases to more testing and are less concerned about lifting restrictions too quickly.

The differences in voting policy preferences related to requiring government-issued photo identification to vote are significant across different racial groups and political affiliations. According to the text, a narrow majority of White Democrats (54%) favor requiring voters to show government-issued photo identification to vote, while larger shares of Black (65%), Hispanic (72%), and Asian Democrats (71%) say the same [2]. Republicans continue to overwhelmingly support this policy (93%) [3]. 

The image data further illustrates these differences. Among White adults, 54% support requiring government-issued photo identification to vote, while 96% of White Republicans support this policy [2][image2]. In contrast, 65% of Black adults, 72% of Hispanic adults, and 71% of Asian adults support this policy [2][image2]. 

Additionally, the image data shows that among Democrats, White adults are as supportive, or in some cases, more supportive, than Black, Hispanic, and Asian adults of policies aimed at making it easier to vote [5][image1]. For example, 81% of Black adults, 63% of Hispanic adults, and 67% of Asian adults support allowing all voters to vote early or absentee, compared to 59% of White adults [6][image1]. 

Overall, the data suggests that there are significant differences in voting policy preferences related to requiring government-issued photo identification to vote, with Republicans and White adults being more supportive of this policy than Democrats and non-White adults.

Racial and ethnic differences significantly influence support for voting policies. According to the text, Black adults are more likely than White, Hispanic, and Asian adults to favor 'no excuse' early, absentee voting [1]. Additionally, while a narrow majority of White Democrats (54%) favor requiring government-issued photo identification to vote, larger shares of Black (65%), Hispanic (72%), and Asian Democrats (71%) support the same policy [2]. 

The images provide further insight. Image 1 shows that 85% of White adults support requiring government-issued photo identification, compared to 78% of Black adults and 78% of Hispanic adults. Asian adults have the highest support at 89% [![{conclusion}](image1)]. Image 2 indicates that 81% of White adults support making Election Day a national holiday, while 75% of Black adults, 71% of Hispanic adults, and 88% of Asian adults agree [![{conclusion}](image2)]. 

Image 3 reveals that 81% of Black adults believe any voter should have the option to vote early or absentee, compared to 59% of White adults, 63% of Hispanic adults, and 67% of Asian adults [![{conclusion}](image3)]. Image 4 shows that 87% of White adults support automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote, while 86% of Black adults, 75% of Hispanic adults, and 79% of Asian adults agree [![{conclusion}](image4)]. Lastly, Image 5 indicates that 96% of White adults support allowing people convicted of felonies to vote after serving their sentences, compared to 65% of Black adults, 90% of Hispanic adults, and 71% of Asian adults [![{conclusion}](image5)].

In conclusion, racial and ethnic differences play a significant role in shaping support for various voting policies, with Black adults generally favoring more expansive voting policies.

The influence of racial and political affiliations on perspectives regarding the requirement for government-issued photo identification to vote is significant. According to the text, White Democrats are less supportive of requiring photo identification compared to Black, Hispanic, and Asian Democrats [6]. Specifically, only 54% of White Democrats favor this requirement, whereas larger shares of Black (65%), Hispanic (72%), and Asian Democrats (71%) support it [6]. This suggests that within the Democratic party, minority groups are more likely to favor photo identification requirements.

In contrast, Republicans are considerably more likely than Democrats to strongly favor photo identification requirements for voting, with 81% of Republicans strongly favoring it compared to 30% of Democrats [9]. This indicates a strong partisan divide on this issue.

When comparing these views to perspectives on voting accessibility policies, the data shows that there are substantial racial and ethnic differences in support for voting policies. For instance, Black Americans are more likely than those of other races and ethnicities to favor allowing people convicted of felonies to vote after serving their sentences, with 85% of Black Americans favoring this policy compared to about seven-in-ten White, Hispanic, and Asian Americans [7]. This highlights that Black Americans are distinctive in their preferences for more expansive voting policies.

Furthermore, the image data supports these findings. Image 1 shows that 96% of White individuals and 90% of Hispanic individuals support requiring photo identification to vote, while 65% of Black individuals and 71% of Asian individuals support it. This aligns with the text data, indicating that White and Hispanic individuals are more likely to support photo identification requirements compared to Black and Asian individuals.

In summary, racial and political affiliations significantly influence perspectives on the requirement for government-issued photo identification to vote, with Republicans and White Democrats being less supportive compared to minority Democrats. Additionally, there are notable differences in support for voting accessibility policies, with Black Americans being more likely to favor expansive voting policies.

The proposal for independent redistricting and early absentee voting options is viewed differently across various political and demographic groups. According to the text, nearly half of U.S. adults approve of the proposal for independent redistricting commissions, with 49% approving, 13% disapproving, and 38% unsure [8]. However, there is a significant partisan divide, with Democrats and Democratic leaners being far more supportive of no-excuse early voting (84%) compared to Republicans (38%) [7].

In terms of early absentee voting, the image shows that 63% of the total population supports allowing any voter to vote early or absentee without a documented reason, while 36% believe a voter should only be allowed to vote early or absentee if they have a documented reason [image1]. This support varies by race and ethnicity, with 81% of Black individuals supporting early or absentee voting, compared to 59% of White individuals, 63% of Hispanic individuals, and 67% of Asian individuals [image1].

Among Republicans, there is a divide between those who voted absentee or by mail (52% support no-excuse absentee or early voting) and those who voted in person on Election Day (22% support) [10]. Among Democrats, there are only slight differences in these views between those who voted absentee and those who voted in person [10].

In conclusion, the proposal for independent redistricting and early absentee voting options is more popular among Democrats and certain demographic groups, while Republicans are more divided on the issue.

The data reveals significant differences in how political affiliations view voting methods and redistricting proposals. 

For voting methods, the data shows that a majority of Democrats and Democratic leaners (90%) support no-excuse absentee or early voting, compared to 52% of Republicans and Republican leaners [4]. Regarding redistricting proposals, the data indicates that 49% of U.S. adults approve of a proposal to end state legislatures' control over congressional redistricting, with only 13% disapproving [1][![{49% approve of redistricting reform}](image5)]. However, there is a notable difference between Republicans and Democrats. While 59% of Democrats approve of the proposal, only 38% of Republicans do [5][![{59% of Democrats approve of redistricting reform}](image5)]. This suggests that Democrats are more supportive of redistricting reform than Republicans.

In conclusion, the data shows that Democrats are more supportive of no-excuse absentee or early voting and redistricting reform than Republicans.

Latino voters' party affiliations have shown a slight shift from 2019 to 2022, with a consistent majority leaning towards the Democratic Party. In 2019, 62% of Latino voters identified with or leaned towards the Democratic Party, while 34% identified with or leaned towards the Republican Party [2]. By 2022, this margin had narrowed slightly, with 64% of Latino voters identifying with or leaning towards the Democratic Party, and 33% identifying with or leaning towards the Republican Party [2]. This indicates a relatively stable party identification among Latino voters over the past few years.

In terms of important election issues, the economy has consistently been the top issue for Latino voters, with 80% considering it very important in both March and August of 2022 [10]. However, there has been a significant rise in the importance of abortion as a voting issue among Latino voters. In March 2022, 42% of Latino voters considered abortion a very important issue, but by August 2022, this number had increased to 57% [8]. This shift is likely a response to the Supreme Court's decision to end the federal guarantee of a right to legal abortion in the United States.

Other top issues for Latino voters in 2022 include health care (71%), violent crime and education (70% each), and gun policy (66%) [10]. These issues have remained relatively stable in importance over the past few months.

The views of Hispanic Democrats and Republicans on the future political role of Trump and the perception of racial discrimination are significantly divergent. According to the data, Hispanic Democrats overwhelmingly disapprove of Trump remaining a national political figure, with 94% expressing this view [4]. In contrast, Hispanic Republicans are more divided, with 35% disapproving and 41% supporting Trump's continued political role [4]. This indicates a stark partisan divide among Hispanics regarding Trump's political future.

Regarding the perception of racial discrimination, Hispanic Democrats are more likely to believe that people do not see racial discrimination where it really does exist, with 73% holding this view [1]. Conversely, Hispanic Republicans are more inclined to think that people see racial discrimination where it does not exist, with 62% expressing this opinion [1]. This suggests that Hispanic Democrats are more attuned to issues of racial discrimination, while Hispanic Republicans are more skeptical about the prevalence of such discrimination.

In summary, Hispanic Democrats and Republicans have markedly different views on Trump's political future and the perception of racial discrimination, reflecting broader partisan divides within the Hispanic community.

Hispanic registered voters' views on Trump's political future are closely tied to their concerns about racial discrimination and gun rights. According to the data, a significant majority of Hispanic registered voters, 73%, believe Trump should not remain a national political figure [4]. This sentiment is particularly strong among Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners, with 94% expressing this view [6]. 

When examining the relationship between these views and concerns about racial discrimination, it is evident that Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners, who are more likely to see racial discrimination where it really does exist (73%), overwhelmingly do not want Trump to remain a political figure [5]. Conversely, Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners, who are less likely to see racial discrimination (62%), are more divided on Trump's political future, with 35% wanting him to remain a political figure [5].

Regarding gun rights, Hispanic registered voters are divided, with 73% prioritizing controlling gun ownership and 26% prioritizing protecting the right to own guns [7]. This division is reflected in their views on Trump, with those who prioritize controlling gun ownership being more likely to want Trump out of politics [7].

In summary, Hispanic registered voters' views on Trump's political future are closely linked to their concerns about racial discrimination and gun rights, with those who are more concerned about racial discrimination and gun control being more likely to want Trump out of politics.

The views on Trump's political future and perceptions of racial discrimination among Hispanic Republicans and Democrats show significant differences. 

Regarding Trump's political future, the data from image5 indicates that a large majority of Hispanic registered voters (73%) believe Trump should not remain a national political figure. Among Hispanic Democrats, this sentiment is even stronger, with 94% stating that Trump should not remain a political figure. In contrast, Hispanic Republicans are more divided, with 35% believing Trump should not remain a political figure, while 41% think he should run for president in 2024, and 21% support another presidential candidate who shares his views.

Perceptions of racial discrimination also vary significantly between Hispanic Republicans and Democrats. Image2 shows that 73% of Hispanic Democrats believe people not seeing racial discrimination where it really does exist is a bigger problem, compared to only 36% of Hispanic Republicans. Conversely, 62% of Hispanic Republicans believe that people seeing racial discrimination where it really does not exist is a bigger problem, while only 25% of Hispanic Democrats share this view.

In summary, Hispanic Democrats overwhelmingly oppose Trump's political future and are more likely to perceive racial discrimination as a significant issue. Hispanic Republicans, on the other hand, are more divided on Trump's political future and are more likely to believe that perceptions of racial discrimination are exaggerated.

The perception of political parties' efforts to earn Latino votes varies significantly among different demographic groups, as illustrated by the data provided. 

From the text quotes, we see that a substantial share of Latino Democrats and Republicans believe there is a great deal of difference between what the parties stand for [1]. However, the perception of effort varies. For instance, 40% of Latino Republicans and Republican-leaning conservatives say that "Republicans work hard to earn Latinos' votes" describes their views at least very well, while only 13% of Latino Democrats agree with the statement that "Democrats work hard to earn people's votes" [3][4]. This suggests a partisan divide in perceptions of effort.

Looking at the image quotes, we can see specific demographic breakdowns. For example, image1 shows that among all Latinos, 36% believe Democrats work hard to earn their votes, compared to only 19% who believe the same about Republicans. This gap is consistent across various subgroups, such as men, women, and different age groups [image1]. 

Image2 and image3 further break down these perceptions by political affiliation and demographic characteristics. For instance, among Democrats and Democratic leaners, majorities of liberals (70%) and conservatives and moderates (61%) say the statement "Democrats work hard to earn people's votes" does not describe their views well [7]. This suggests that even within the same party, there are differences in perceptions based on political ideology.

Image4 and image5 provide additional insights into the perceptions of effort by political parties. For example, among all Latinos, 52% say that neither party works "Not too/Not at all well" to earn their votes, while 26% say that both parties work "Somewhat well" [image4]. This suggests a general dissatisfaction with the efforts of both parties.

In conclusion, the data suggests that there is a significant partisan divide in perceptions of effort by political parties to earn Latino votes. This divide is consistent across various demographic groups and is influenced by political ideology. The overall dissatisfaction with the efforts of both parties suggests that there is room for improvement in how political parties engage with Latino voters.

The perceptions of the Democratic and Republican parties' efforts to engage with Latino voters vary significantly among different political affiliations. According to the data, a majority of Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners (56%) believe that the Democratic Party works hard to earn Latino votes, while only about a third (35%) of Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners think the Republican Party makes similar efforts [1]. This suggests a perception gap where each party is seen as more engaged by the opposing party's supporters.

The image data further illustrates these perceptions. For instance, 71% of respondents believe the Democratic Party works hard to earn Latino votes, with 35% saying it does so "somewhat well" and 36% saying "very/extremely well" [4]. In contrast, only 45% of respondents feel the same about the Republican Party, with 26% saying it does so "somewhat well" and 19% saying "very/extremely well" [4]. This indicates a stronger perception of engagement from the Democratic Party.

Moreover, the image data shows that 63% of respondents believe the Democratic Party really cares about Latinos, compared to only 34% who feel the same about the Republican Party [4]. This disparity is also reflected in the belief that the Democratic Party represents the interests of people like the respondents, with 60% agreeing compared to 34% for the Republican Party [4].

Over recent years, these perceptions have been reflected in party affiliation trends among Latino voters. The image data indicates that the Democratic Party has maintained a strong lead in party affiliation among Latinos, with 66% identifying as Democrats or leaning towards the Democratic Party in 2021, compared to 31% for the Republican Party [2]. This trend has shown little change over the past few years, suggesting a stable preference for the Democratic Party among Latino voters.

In conclusion, the perceptions of the Democratic and Republican parties' efforts to engage with Latino voters are significantly different among various political affiliations, with the Democratic Party generally perceived as more engaged and caring. These perceptions have contributed to the Democratic Party's strong and stable lead in party affiliation among Latino voters over recent years.

The perception of higher pay in STEM jobs is generally similar among men and women, with both groups valuing it highly. However, there are notable differences in the job characteristics that men and women in STEM value. According to the data, men in STEM jobs place a higher emphasis on opportunities for promotion and having a high-paying job. Specifically, 57% of men value opportunities for promotion compared to 46% of women [9]. Similarly, 59% of men value having a high-paying job, whereas only 48% of women do [9].

On the other hand, women in STEM jobs are more inclined to value job characteristics that focus on helping others and making a meaningful contribution to society. For instance, 59% of women value having a job focused on helping others, compared to only 31% of men [9]. Additionally, 60% of women value making a meaningful contribution to society, while 51% of men do [9].

In summary, while both men and women in STEM jobs value higher pay, men tend to prioritize opportunities for promotion and high-paying jobs, whereas women place more importance on helping others and making a meaningful contribution to society.

![Men in STEM jobs value opportunities for promotion and high-paying jobs more than women](image1)

The differences in job characteristics valued by men and women in STEM are significant. According to the text [7], both men and women in STEM jobs value job flexibility, but women are more likely to want a job that helps others. The image [4] further supports this, showing that women in STEM value having a job focused on helping others more than men do. Additionally, the text [10] highlights that women in STEM jobs are more likely to consider gender discrimination a major reason for the underrepresentation of women in STEM, with 48% of women feeling this way compared to 29% of men.

The perceived difficulties faced by women in entering the STEM workforce are closely related to these job characteristic values. The image [3] shows that 39% of women face discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotion, which can discourage them from pursuing STEM careers. Furthermore, the lack of female role models in STEM, as shown in the image [3], can also contribute to the underrepresentation of women in the field. The text [4] emphasizes the importance of quality schooling and early encouragement for girls to pursue STEM fields, which can help address these challenges and increase the number of women in STEM jobs. The main reasons for the underrepresentation of women in STEM jobs include facing discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotions (39%), not being encouraged to pursue STEM from an early age (39%), and finding it more difficult to balance work and family in STEM jobs (33%). The self-identification of Hispanics in the U.S. is influenced by several factors, which vary across different generations. According to the text, by the third generation, only 77% of individuals with Hispanic ancestry self-identify as Hispanic, and this percentage drops to 50% by the fourth or higher generation [1]. This trend suggests that as individuals become more distanced from their immigrant roots, their likelihood of self-identifying as Hispanic decreases.

The image data further elucidates these generational differences. For instance, among foreign-born Hispanics, 65% self-identify as Hispanic, while this figure drops to 36% among the second generation and further to 26% among the third or higher generation [image1]. This decline indicates that factors such as birth in the U.S., upbringing, and limited contact with Hispanic relatives play significant roles in shaping Hispanic identity across generations.

Additionally, the image data highlights other factors influencing self-identification. For example, 27% of individuals with Hispanic ancestry do not self-identify as Hispanic due to a mixed background or Hispanic ancestry that is too far back [image2]. Similarly, 16% cite upbringing or lack of contact with Hispanic relatives, and 15% do not speak Spanish or have no cultural link to Hispanic culture as reasons for not self-identifying as Hispanic.

The image data also shows that among self-identified Hispanics, 50% identify by country of origin or heritage, while 23% identify as Hispanic/Latino and another 23% identify as American [image3]. This distribution suggests that cultural and national identity factors significantly influence how Hispanics self-identify.

Furthermore, the image data indicates that speaking Spanish and having a Spanish last name are not crucial factors for self-identifying as Hispanic. Only 17% of individuals with Hispanic ancestry believe that speaking Spanish is necessary to be considered Hispanic, and 81% do not [image4]. Similarly, only 15% believe that having a Spanish last name is necessary, while 84% do not [image5].

In conclusion, the self-identification of Hispanics in the U.S. is influenced by a combination of factors, including generational distance from immigrant roots, mixed background, upbringing, cultural links, and national identity. These factors vary across generations, with a general trend of decreasing self-identification as Hispanic as individuals become more distanced from their immigrant roots.

The experiences of attending cultural celebrations and parental pride discussions among generations of self-identified Hispanics and non-Hispanics show a clear generational decline in engagement with Hispanic culture. 

For self-identified Hispanics, the data reveals that 59% of foreign-born Hispanics often attended cultural celebrations, while this percentage drops to 49% for the second generation and further to 35% for the third or higher generation [6]. Similarly, discussions about parental pride in their country of origin roots are most frequent among immigrant and second-generation Hispanics (57% and 50%, respectively), but significantly decrease to 33% by the third generation [7].

In contrast, self-identified non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry show much lower engagement. Only 9% report that their parents often took them to cultural celebrations, and a mere 15% of this group report that their parents often encouraged them to speak Spanish [1, 3].

The growth in digital media and e-commerce has significantly impacted the landscape for digital advertising and online sales between 2014 and 2018. 

From 2014 to 2018, e-commerce sales in India saw a substantial increase, with product e-commerce growing from $3 billion to $13 billion, and travel and other sectors growing from $8 billion to $30 billion, as shown in ![e-commerce sales growth](image1). This growth was driven by factors such as infrastructure development, smartphone penetration, and the increasing use of digital payments, as mentioned in [3].

The digital advertising spend also saw a significant rise, with a CAGR of 29.9% from 2012 to 2016, as highlighted in ![digital ad spend growth](image5). This growth in digital advertising is indicative of the increasing importance of digital media in reaching consumers.

Additionally, the shift in payment methods from cash on delivery (COD) to digital payments, including credit cards, debit cards, net banking, EMI, and third-party wallets, reflects the growing digitalization of the economy. By 2016, the share of COD shipments was reducing, and digital payments were on the rise, as shown in ![payment method shift](image4).

Overall, the growth in digital media and e-commerce has led to a significant increase in digital advertising spend and online sales, transforming the landscape of the Indian market.

The primary factors driving the growth in eCommerce sales from 2014 to 2018 include the increasing number of debit card users in India, as indicated by the text quote [1], and the rising adoption of digital payments, as highlighted in the text quote [3]. The image quote ![image2](image2) shows a significant increase in the number of debit card users from 399 million in 2014 to 584.02 million in 2016, which correlates with the growth in eCommerce sales. Additionally, the text quote [3] mentions that the share of cash on delivery (CoD) shipments is reducing, and there is an uptick in EMI payments and the use of third-party wallets, which are also contributing to the growth in eCommerce sales.

The evolution of payment methods and consumer demographics significantly influences e-commerce opportunities in India. 

Firstly, the shift in payment methods is evident. In 2013, cash on delivery (COD) dominated with 60% of transactions, but by 2016, this dropped to 50% [4]. Meanwhile, digital payments such as credit cards, debit cards, and net banking saw increases, with third-party wallets emerging as a new trend [6]. This shift indicates a growing comfort and preference for digital transactions, which opens up opportunities for e-commerce platforms to innovate and offer more digital payment options.

![Payment Methods Evolution](image4)

Secondly, consumer demographics play a crucial role. The majority of e-commerce users fall within the 26-35 age bracket, accounting for 55% of the market [5]. This age group is typically more tech-savvy and open to online shopping, making them a prime target for e-commerce businesses. Additionally, the increasing number of debit card users in India, projected to be half of the population by 2016 [6], further supports the growth of digital transactions.

![Consumer Demographics](image5)

In conclusion, the transition from traditional to digital payment methods, coupled with a young and tech-savvy consumer base, presents significant opportunities for e-commerce growth in India. Businesses that adapt to these trends by enhancing digital payment options and targeting the younger demographic are likely to thrive.

The organizational structure of the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) is depicted in image3. ISRO is under the administrative control of the Department of Space (DOS), which is overseen by the Prime Minister. The Space Commission, also under the Prime Minister, formulates policies and oversees the implementation of the Indian space program. ISRO is responsible for the development and application of space science and technology for the socio-economic benefit of the country, as stated in [7].

ISRO's budget allocation for the years 2015-2016 and 2016-2017 is shown in image1. The budget is divided into several categories, including Space Technology, Space Applications, INSAT Operational, Space Sciences, Direction & Administration, and Other Programmes. The total budget for 2015-2016 was 7388.19, and for 2016-2017, it was 7509.14. The largest portion of the budget is allocated to Space Technology, with 4596.2 and 5235.68 for the respective years. Space Applications and INSAT Operational also receive significant funding, while Space Sciences and Direction & Administration receive smaller allocations. The remaining budget is allocated to Other Programmes.

In conclusion, the organizational structure of ISRO is hierarchical, with the Prime Minister at the top, followed by the Space Commission, DOS, and ISRO. The budget allocation for ISRO is focused on Space Technology, with significant funding also going to Space Applications and INSAT Operational. The budget for 2016-2017 shows a slight increase compared to 2015-2016. ![Organizational structure of ISRO](image3) ![Budget allocation for ISRO](image1)

The Indian Space Programme is a comprehensive initiative that encompasses various centers, each with distinct roles and significance. These centers are crucial for the development and application of space science and technology for the socio-economic benefit of the country. The budget allocation for these centers reflects their importance and the focus areas of the Indian Space Programme.

### Roles and Significance of Different Centers:

1. **ISRO (Indian Space Research Organisation)**:
   - **Role**: ISRO is the primary agency responsible for space exploration and satellite technology. It oversees the development and launch of satellites, space vehicles, and space-related technologies.
   - **Significance**: ISRO plays a pivotal role in advancing India's space capabilities, conducting space missions, and providing space-based services for various applications such as communication, navigation, and earth observation.

2. **Antrix Corporation Limited**:
   - **Role**: Antrix is the commercial arm of ISRO, responsible for the marketing and commercial exploitation of space products and services.
   - **Significance**: Antrix facilitates the development of space-related industrial capabilities in India and provides end-to-end solutions for space products and services to international customers.

3. **Space Commission**:
   - **Role**: The Space Commission formulates policies and oversees the implementation of the Indian space programme.
   - **Significance**: It ensures the strategic direction and coordination of space activities across various institutions and centers.

4. **Physical Research Laboratory (PRL)**:
   - **Role**: PRL conducts research in space science, including planetary exploration, astrophysics, and space technology.
   - **Significance**: PRL contributes to the scientific understanding of space and supports the development of space missions.

5. **National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL)**:
   - **Role**: NARL focuses on atmospheric research, including radar applications, ionospheric studies, and weather and climate research.
   - **Significance**: NARL's research helps in understanding and predicting atmospheric phenomena, which is crucial for various applications such as weather forecasting and climate studies.

6. **North Eastern-Space Applications Centre (NE-SAC)**:
   - **Role**: NE-SAC provides developmental support to the North Eastern Region using space science and technology.
   - **Significance**: It aims to enhance the socio-economic development of the North Eastern states through the application of space technology.

7. **Semi-Conductor Laboratory (SCL)**:
   - **Role**: SCL focuses on the design, development, fabrication, assembly,

The National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL) and the Semiconductor Laboratory (SCL) are both key institutions under the Department of Space (DOS) in India, each with distinct primary functions and facilities that support their respective missions.

### National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL)
**Primary Functions:**
- NARL is dedicated to atmospheric research with a vision to "Developing capability to predict the behaviour of the earth’s atmosphere through observations and modeling." [4]
- The laboratory focuses on technology development, observations, data archival, dissemination, assimilation, and modeling. [4]

**Facilities:**
- NARL operates under seven major groups, including Radar Application and Development Group, Ionospheric and Space Research Group, Atmospheric Structure and Dynamics Group, Cloud and Convective Systems Group, Aerosols, Radiation and Trace Gases Group, Weather and Climate Research Group, and Computers and Data Management Group. [10]
- Specific projects such as the LIDAR project and Advanced Space-borne Instrument Development project are also undertaken. [10]

### Semiconductor Laboratory (SCL)
**Primary Functions:**
- SCL aims to create a strong microelectronics base in the country and enhance capabilities in the VLSI domain. [8]
- The laboratory focuses on the design, development, fabrication, assembly, testing, and reliability assurance of CMOS and MEMS devices. [8]

**Facilities:**
- SCL has upgraded its Wafer Fabrication Lab, which now includes an $8" CMOS Wafer Fabrication Line geared up for production activities. [9]
- The lab has successfully processed three production lots with ASICs/IPs/Test Chips designed in-house, including the Vikram Processor for Launch Vehicles. [9]

### Conclusion
Both NARL and SCL play crucial roles in advancing India's capabilities in atmospheric research and semiconductor technology, respectively. Their facilities are tailored to support their specific research and development goals, contributing significantly to the country's scientific and technological advancements.

![NARL and SCL facilities support their primary functions in atmospheric research and semiconductor technology.](image4)

The comparison of streaming and album sales shares across different music genres reveals significant insights into music consumption trends. 

From the text quotes, we know that streaming has become the leading format in the music industry [4]. This is further supported by the data in the images. 

In the image showing the breakdown of total activity, album sales, and song sales by genre (image1), we can see that streaming (red bars) dominates in most genres. For instance, in Rock, streaming accounts for 82%, while album sales (orange bars) are at 63%. In Pop, streaming is at 58%, and album sales are at 21%. This trend is consistent across R&B/Hip-Hop, Country, and other genres, indicating a strong preference for streaming over traditional album sales.

The second image (image2) provides a more detailed breakdown, showing that streaming (SEA) is the largest share in all genres, with particularly high percentages in Latin (68%) and Dance/Electronic (51%). This suggests that streaming is not only popular but also essential for the success of music in these genres.

The third image (image3) lists the top 10 albums and their respective shares of album sales, song sales, and on-demand audio streams. It shows that even for the top-selling albums, streaming plays a significant role, with some albums like "To Pimp a Butterfly" by Kendrick Lamar having an 84% streaming share.

The fourth image (image4) further supports this trend by showing the percentage of album sales, song sales, and streams for different genres. For example, in Rock, album sales are at 37%, while streams are at 24%. In R&B/Hip-Hop, album sales are at 18%, and streams are at 26%. This indicates that while album sales still hold a significant share, streaming is rapidly catching up and, in many cases, surpassing traditional sales.

The fifth image (image5) provides a summary of the total music market, showing that streaming accounts for 70% of total activity, while album sales are at 51%. This suggests that streaming is the dominant mode of music consumption, with album sales playing a secondary role.

In conclusion, the data clearly shows that streaming is the leading format in the music industry, with a significant share across all genres. This suggests that music consumption trends are shifting towards streaming, with consumers increasingly preferring the convenience and accessibility of streaming services over traditional album purchases

The contribution of streams to total music activity varies significantly between genres and total music consumption. 

For total music activity, streams account for 70% of the activity, as shown in image4. This indicates that streaming is the dominant format in overall music consumption.

When examining specific genres, the contribution of streams varies:

- **Rock**: Streams make up 26% of total activity, as seen in image2. This is lower than the overall average, indicating that rock music has a higher reliance on album and song sales compared to streaming.
  
- **R&B/Hip-Hop**: Streams contribute 39% to total activity, as shown in image2. This is higher than the overall average, suggesting that R&B/Hip-Hop fans are more likely to stream music compared to other formats.
  
- **Pop**: Streams account for 36% of total activity, as seen in image2. This is slightly below the overall average, indicating a balanced consumption pattern across different formats.
  
- **Country**: Streams contribute 18% to total activity, as shown in image2. This is significantly lower than the overall average, indicating that country music fans prefer other formats over streaming.

- **Latin**: Streams make up 68% of total activity, as seen in image2. This is much higher than the overall average, showing a strong preference for streaming among Latin music fans.

- **Dance/Elec**: Streams account for 51% of total activity, as shown in image2. This is slightly above the overall average, indicating a higher reliance on streaming in this genre.

- **Christian/Gosp**: Streams contribute 27% to total activity, as seen in image2. This is lower than the overall average, suggesting that Christian/Gospel music fans prefer other formats over streaming.

In summary, while streaming is the leading format in total music activity, its contribution varies across genres, with Latin and R&B/Hip-Hop showing a higher reliance on streaming, and Rock and Country showing a lower reliance.

The catalog shares of different music formats vary significantly across genres. In Rock, album sales account for 37%, song sales for 24%, and streams for 23% [image3]. For R&B/Hip-Hop, album sales are 18%, song sales 23%, and streams 26% [image3]. Pop has album sales at 11%, song sales at 26%, and streams at 19% [image3]. Country music shows album sales at 12%, song sales at 11%, and streams at 12% [image3].

The albums with the highest on-demand audio stream share are "To Pimp a Butterfly" by Kendrick Lamar with 84% [image2], followed by "Pinkprint" by Nicki Minaj with 18% [image2]. These figures highlight the dominance of streaming in certain genres and for specific albums.

In 2015, the music genres varied significantly in their share across different sales formats and streaming. 

Rock dominated album sales with 37% [1], while R&B/Hip-Hop led in streaming with 39% [3]. Pop had the highest song sales at 31% [3], and Country had a balanced distribution with 35% in physical albums and 27% in streaming [3]. 

The overall activity shows that Rock had the highest total activity at 57% [4], followed by R&B/Hip-Hop at 52% [4]. Pop and Country had similar total activities at 51% and 55%, respectively [4]. 

Streaming was the leading format overall, with 70% of total activity [4]. Rock had the highest album sales at 32% [3], while R&B/Hip-Hop had the highest streaming at 39% [3]. 

In summary, Rock was the biggest genre in album sales, R&B/Hip-Hop led in streaming, and Pop was strong in song sales.

The distribution of music sales formats varies significantly across different genres. According to the data, Rock is driven by album sales, with 63% of its total activity coming from album sales [5], while Pop is mainly driven by streaming, with 61% of its total activity coming from streams [5]. R&B/Hip-Hop also relies heavily on streaming, with 70% of its total activity coming from streams [5]. Country music, on the other hand, has a more balanced distribution, with 55% of its total activity coming from album sales and 48% from streams [5].

In terms of which genres rely most on streaming, R&B/Hip-Hop leads with 70% of its total activity coming from streams [5], followed closely by Pop with 61% [5]. Rock, while still significant, has a lower reliance on streaming at 51% [5]. Country music has the lowest reliance on streaming at 48% [5].

The shares of music consumption formats differ significantly between rock and R&B/hip-hop genres. In the rock genre, album sales dominate with 37% [1], followed by streams at 23% [1]. In contrast, R&B/hip-hop is driven more by streams, which account for 26% [1], while album sales are lower at 18% [1].

This indicates that rock music consumers prefer purchasing albums, whereas R&B/hip-hop listeners are more inclined towards streaming music. The higher streaming percentage in R&B/hip-hop suggests a greater reliance on digital platforms for music consumption in this genre. 

![Rock is driven by catalog at all formats while pop is mainly driven by current](image1)

The trends in streaming and album sales across different music genres reveal significant variations that have notable implications for the music industry.

Firstly, the data shows that streaming has become the dominant format across all genres, with a total share of 70% [1][2][7]. This is evident from the bar chart in image1, which illustrates that streams account for 70% of total music activity, far surpassing album sales (51%) and song sales (49%).

When examining specific genres, the bar chart in image3 provides a detailed breakdown. Rock music, for instance, has a high total activity of 82%, with streams making up 68% of this activity. Album sales contribute 63%, and song sales account for 68% [3]. This indicates that while rock is driven by catalog sales, streaming still plays a significant role.

The system generates a response to the user's request through a series of steps involving various components of the dialogue system. Initially, the user's input is processed by a Bi-LSTM Utterance Encoder, which converts the natural language input into a continuous vector representation. This encoded user utterance, along with the encoding of the previous system action, is then fed into an LSTM Dialogue State component. The LSTM Dialogue State maintains a continuous representation of the dialogue state, which is updated after each dialogue turn by incorporating the user's utterance and the previous system action [4].

The dialogue state is crucial for dialogue state tracking, which involves maintaining the state of the conversation, such as the user's goals, by accumulating evidence from the sequence of dialogue turns. The model updates its estimation of the user's goal, represented by a list of slot-value pairs, and maintains a probability distribution over candidate values for each goal slot type [7].

Based on the dialogue state, the system formulates a query command to retrieve requested information from a knowledge base. The query results are then encoded and used as input to the policy network, which emits a system action in the form of a dialogue act. This system action is conditioned on information from the dialogue state, the estimated user's goal, and the encoding of the query results [4].

Finally, the system action, together with the user goal tracking results and the retrieved knowledge base entities, is used to generate the final natural language system response via a natural language generator (NLG). The NLG uses a template-based approach, where delexicalized tokens in the NLG template are replaced by values from either the estimated user goal values or the knowledge base entities, depending on the emitted system action [6].

In summary, the system generates a response by encoding the user's input, updating the dialogue state, formulating and executing a query to the knowledge base, and finally generating a natural language response based on the system action and retrieved information. This process ensures that the system's response is contextually relevant and aligned with the user's request. ![The system architecture shows the flow of information from user input to system response, involving components like the Bi-LSTM Utterance Encoder, LSTM Dialogue State, and Natural Language Generator.](image2) ![The policy network diagram illustrates how the system action is determined based on the dialogue state, slot value logits, and query results encoding.](image3)

The SnapNTell dataset stands out from other Visual Question Answering (VQA) datasets in several key aspects. Firstly, it encompasses a diverse range of fine-grained entities, each accompanied by corresponding representative images. This is evident from the table in image1, which lists 22 categories with a total of 7,568 unique entities. In contrast, other datasets like ViQuAE and Encyclopedic VQA, while incorporating entity-level knowledge, do not match the variety and specificity of entities in SnapNTell [5].

Secondly, the SnapNTell dataset features QA pairs that require extensive knowledge for accurate responses, with entity names specifically mentioned in the answer sets. This is highlighted in image2, where the question-answer pairs demand detailed, entity-specific knowledge, unlike the simpler binary answers found in other datasets [4].

Furthermore, the SnapNTell dataset boasts a higher count of images and a longer average length for answers. Specifically, it includes 10 images for each entity, whereas the exact number of images per entity in ViQuAE and Encyclopedic VQA remains unspecified [5]. The table in image5 also shows that SnapNTell has 75,680 QA pairs and an average answer length of 25.7 words, significantly more than other datasets [5].

In terms of knowledge, the SnapNTell dataset is designed to test models' capabilities in identifying entities and providing detailed, entity-specific knowledge in their responses. This is a notable improvement over existing VQA datasets, which often fall short in serving this purpose due to a narrow range of entity categories and overly simplistic yes/no QA pairs [2].

In summary, the SnapNTell dataset surpasses existing VQA datasets in terms of the variety of categories, the number of distinct entities, the overall number of QA pairs, and the depth of knowledge required for accurate responses. It is structured to include 10 images for each entity and features highly anonymous questions, making it a comprehensive and challenging benchmark for entity-centric VQA [4][5][6].

Based on the provided text and image quotes, the model with the highest test median score is BERT (Large). The test median score for BERT (Large) is 0.712, as shown in Table 1 [1] and Table 4 [4]. 

The architecture of the BERT model is visualized in Figure 3 [2]. The claim and reason are joined to form the first text segment, which is paired with each warrant and independently processed. The final layer CLS vector is passed to a linear layer to obtain the logits \( z_{j}^{(i)} \). The whole architecture is fine-tuned. The learning rate is \( 2e^{-5} \), and a maximum of 20 training epochs is allowed, taking the parameters from the epoch with the best validation set accuracy. The Hugging Face PyTorch implementation is used.

![BERT architecture](image5) 

In conclusion, BERT (Large) has the highest test median score of 0.712, and its architecture involves joining the claim and reason to form the first text segment, which is then paired with each warrant and processed independently. The final layer CLS vector is passed to a linear layer to obtain the logits, and the model is fine-tuned with a learning rate of \( 2e^{-5} \) and a maximum of 20 training epochs.

Additionally, [7] mentions that learned spatial encodings passed to the attentions give similar results to fixed sine spatial positional encodings, suggesting that the model can adapt to different types of positional encodings as long as they are provided at the attention layers.

The ProgramFC model demonstrates superior performance compared to FLAN-T5 across various model sizes and task complexities. As shown in [8], ProgramFC maintains its effectiveness even with smaller model sizes, such as FLAN-T5-small, achieving comparable performance to the much larger FLAN-T5-XXL model for 4-hop claims. This indicates that the program-guided reasoning approach of ProgramFC is particularly beneficial for smaller models, which typically struggle with complex reasoning tasks.

In terms of task complexity, ProgramFC shows a smaller performance drop as the number of reasoning hops increases, compared to FLAN-T5. For instance, on the HOVER dataset, the F1 score of FLAN-T5 drops significantly from 2-hop to 4-hop claims, whereas ProgramFC's performance drop is much smaller [10].

Regarding retrieval recall, ProgramFC outperforms one-step retrieval methods across all datasets, with the most notable improvement observed on HOVER 4-hop claims, where ProgramFC achieves a 37.1% higher recall rate [6]. This is illustrated in ![ProgramFC outperforms one-step retrieval on all datasets, with the largest improvement of 37.1% on HOVER 4-hop](image2).

In summary, ProgramFC not only maintains high performance across different model sizes and task complexities but also significantly enhances the retrieval of relevant evidence, leading to better overall fact-checking results.

To understand how ProgramFC's performance compares with other models across different fact-checking tasks, we can analyze the results presented in the text and images.

First, let's look at the performance comparison between ProgramFC and FLAN-T5 using different language model sizes. According to [1 ], ProgramFC is particularly effective when the model size is small. The performance of the end-to-end FLAN-T5 model decreases significantly with decreasing model size, but this trend is less notable for ProgramFC. The high-level reasoning plan offered by reasoning programs substantially alleviates the demands on the subsequent sub-task solvers. The results show that the program-guided model using FLAN-T5-small (80M parameters) as sub-task solvers can achieve comparable performance to the $137\mathrm{x}$ larger FLAN-T5-XXL (11B) model with end-to-end reasoning for 4-hop claims.

Next, let's examine the performance of ProgramFC on different fact-checking tasks. According to [ 5 ], ProgramFC outperforms one-step retrieval on all datasets, with the largest improvement of $37.1\%$ on HOVER 4-hop. This is because some information may not be present in the original claim, but is only revealed during the reasoning process. Iterative retrieval guided by the reasoning program yields better results.

Now, let's analyze the error trends in ProgramFC's predictions. According to [ 2 ], the errors in ProgramFC's predictions can be classified into three categories: (i) Syntactic errors, where the program does not conform to the defined grammar and cannot be parsed, (ii) Semantic errors, which include incorrect or missing arguments/variables (Token), incorrect program structure (Structure), and incorrect sub-task calls (Subtask), and (iii) Incorrect execution, where the program is correct, but where the incorrect prediction is a result of its execution.

The error analysis in Table 2 (not provided in the text) shows that no syntax errors were found in the samples, indicating that Codex effectively generates executable programs through few-shot in-context learning. However, as the complexity of the claims increases, the proportion of semantic errors in the programs also increases, with structural errors becoming particularly prevalent. This highlights the difficulty of generating the appropriate step-by-step reasoning strategies for claims that require long-chain reasoning.

In conclusion, ProgramFC's performance is comparable to larger end-to-end models, and it outperforms one-step retrieval on all datasets. The error trends in Program

The 'hard-to-contrast' strategy, as highlighted in the text and visualized in the images, consistently outperforms other querying strategies across various datasets. This is evident from the performance metrics shown in the images, where the 'hard-to-contrast' strategy achieves higher AUC scores compared to other methods such as 'easy-to-learn', 'consistency', 'margin', 'VAAL', 'entropy', 'coreset', and 'BALD'. For instance, in image1, the 'hard-to-contrast' strategy (red line) shows superior performance in terms of AUC across different datasets like OrganAMNIST, BloodMNIST, and PathMNIST. Similarly, in image2, the 'hard-to-contrast' strategy demonstrates a higher AUC score as the number of images increases, indicating its effectiveness in improving model performance with more data.

Moreover, the 'hard-to-contrast' strategy significantly influences the initial query selection by providing a more informative and diverse set of data points. This is crucial for addressing the cold start problem in active learning, as discussed in the text. The strategy's ability to select data points that are difficult to contrast, without relying on ground truths, makes it a practical and effective solution for initial query selection. This is further supported by the quantitative comparisons in image3, where the 'hard-to-contrast' strategy is shown to cover 100% of classes in low budget scenarios, outperforming other strategies in terms of label diversity and data coverage.

In conclusion, the 'hard-to-contrast' strategy not only outperforms other querying strategies across different datasets but also significantly enhances the initial query selection process by ensuring label diversity and optimal data coverage. This makes it a robust and reliable approach for active learning in image classification tasks.

To address the question of how different instruction formats and demonstration selections impact the performance of ChatGPT and Codex on the FewNERD dataset, we can refer to the findings from the provided text and images.

### Instruction Formats
From the text [1], it is mentioned that diverse instruction strategies yield comparable results in the IE task. This suggests that the specific format of the instruction does not significantly affect the performance of LLMs like ChatGPT and Codex. This is further supported by the box plot in `![{Instruction format does not significantly affect performance}](image3)`, which shows that the F1 scores for different instruction formats are relatively similar, indicating that the choice of instruction format has a limited impact on performance.

### Demonstration Selections
The text [10] highlights that both sentence embedding and EPR surpass random sampling by a large margin. This is visually represented in `![{Sentence embedding and EPR outperform random sampling}](image3)`, where the box plots for sentence embedding and EPR have higher medians compared to random sampling. This indicates that the selection strategy of demonstrations matters, and retrieval based on sentence embedding is particularly effective.

### Comparison with Other Models
The line graphs in `![{ChatGPT and Codex performance on FewNERD}](image1)` and `![{ChatGPT and Codex performance on TACREV and TACRED}](image5)` provide a comparative analysis of different models, including ChatGPT and Codex, on the FewNERD dataset. The graphs show that while ChatGPT and Codex perform reasonably well, especially in low-shot settings, their performance plateaus as the number of shots increases. This is in contrast to fine-tuned models, which show a more consistent improvement with more shots.

### Conclusion
In conclusion, the performance of ChatGPT and Codex on the FewNERD dataset is moderately affected by the instruction format but significantly influenced by the demonstration selection strategy. Sentence embedding and EPR are more effective than random sampling. Compared to other models, ChatGPT and Codex perform well in low-shot settings but tend to plateau as the number of shots increases. Therefore, while LLMs like ChatGPT and Codex are powerful, their performance can be optimized with careful selection of demonstration strategies.

Common error types in the dataset include grounding errors, ambiguity errors, calculation errors, and program errors [3]. Grounding errors, where the program incorrectly associates data with the respective cells in the table, are the most prevalent, accounting for 50% of the errors [5]. Ambiguity errors, where the claim contains ambiguous expressions that the program fails to represent, make up 22% of the errors. Calculation errors, where incorrect floating point arithmetic calculation in Python lead to inaccurate results, account for 20% of the errors. Program errors, which encompass mistakes such as incorrect or missing arguments/variables, and erroneous operations, make up 8% of the errors.

The relationship between the reasoning types and the error types can be inferred from the data. For instance, grounding errors are likely to occur in reasoning types that involve retrieving specific values from the table, such as simple lookup and comparison. Ambiguity errors are likely to occur in reasoning types that involve extracting information from context sentences in the table caption or article, such as closed-domain knowledge and open-domain knowledge. Calculation errors are likely to occur in reasoning types that involve performing arithmetic operations, such as subtraction and division. Program errors are likely to occur in reasoning types that involve generating Python programs to perform the reasoning, such as all the reasoning types in the dataset.

In conclusion, the ScITab dataset involves a variety of reasoning types, with simple lookup and comparison being the most common. The distribution of reasoning steps suggests a moderate level of complexity in reasoning. The primary reasons for refuted claims in the SciTab dataset include incorrect calculation results, wrong approximation words, partially correct claims, mismatched values in the claim, and incorrect operation types. These reasons are detailed in the table provided in the image, where incorrect calculation results account for 41.7% of refuted claims, and wrong approximation words account for 33.3% [image1].

In terms of performance, various large language models (LLMs) have been evaluated in both zero-shot and in-context settings. The results indicate that the best-performing model in the zero-shot 2-class setting is Vicuna-7B with a score of 63.62, while in the 3-class setting, FLAN-T5-XL achieves the highest score of  38.05 [3]. However, these scores are only moderately better than random guessing, highlighting the challenging nature of the SciTab dataset.

In the in-context setting, models are provided with three hold-out examples as demonstrations, and the results show improved performance. For instance, the Flan-T5-XXL model achieves a score of  60.48 in the 3-class setting, which is a significant improvement over the zero-shot setting [image4].

The discrepancy in performance between the zero-shot and in-context settings suggests that providing models with a few examples can significantly enhance their fact-checking capabilities. This is particularly evident in the 3-class setting, where the inclusion of the NEI (Not Enough Information) class tends to diminish the models' confidence, causing a shift in their predictions from 'supported/refuted' to 'NEI' [8].

Overall, while LLMs have shown some promise in fact-checking claims in the SciTab dataset, there is still a significant gap between their performance and that of human annotators, who can achieve F1 scores of  92.46 and  84.73 in the 2-class and 3-class settings, respectively [5]. This underscores the need for continued research and development in this area to improve the accuracy and reliability of LLMs in scientific fact-checking.

The primary reasons for refuted claims in ScITaB include incorrect calculation results (41.7%), incorrect approximation words (33.3%), and partially correct claims (10.0%) [4]. For NEI claims, the main reasons are insufficient matching evidence (33.3%), lack of open-domain knowledge (25.0%), and lack of closed-domain knowledge (15.0%) [4]. These reasons highlight the complexity of scientific fact-checking, where numerical reasoning, domain-specific knowledge, and ambiguity play significant roles.

In the zero-shot 3-class classification, models struggle with distinguishing between 'refuted' and 'NEI' claims, as evidenced by the confusion matrices for InstructGPT and GPT-4 [6]. InstructGPT frequently classifies supported and refuted claims as 'NEI', while GPT-4 incorrectly categorizes NEI claims as either supported or refuted. This difficulty is reflected in the performance metrics, where the best model, GPT-4+CoT, achieves a 3-class F1 score of 63.21, which is only moderately better than random guessing [2]. The performance gap between models and human annotators further underscores the challenges posed by the NEI class and the need for more sophisticated reasoning capabilities in LLMs.

This suggests that distinguishing whether a claim is verifiable is a key challenge for both models on the S CI T AB dataset.

Grounding errors occur when the program incorrectly associates data with the respective cells in the table. Ambiguity errors arise when the claim contains ambiguous expressions that the program fails to represent. Calculation errors happen due to incorrect floating point arithmetic calculations in Python. Program errors encompass mistakes such as incorrect or missing arguments/variables, and erroneous operations.

The estimated proportion of these error types is shown in Figure 13 [4]. Grounding errors account for 50% of the errors, followed by ambiguity errors at 22%, calculation errors at 20%, and program errors at 8%. This highlights the difficulty in accurately referencing the specific cells to which a claim refers and the challenges posed by the ambiguous nature of scientific claims.

In conclusion, the performance differences between InstructGPT and GPT-4 on the zero-shot 3-class classification task can be attributed to their distinct error patterns and the types of errors they encounter. Grounding errors, ambiguity errors, calculation errors, and program errors all contribute to the challenges faced by these models in accurately predicting the veracity of scientific claims on the S CI T AB dataset.

The MMMU dataset is meticulously curated to assess the expert-level multimodal understanding capability of foundation models across a broad scope of tasks. It covers 30 subjects across 6 disciplines, including Art, Business, Health & Medicine, Science, Humanities & Social Science, and Tech & Engineering, and over 183 subfields [4]. The questions in our benchmark were manually collected by a team of 50 college students (including coauthors) from various disciplines and subjects, drawing from online sources, textbooks, and lecture materials [4].

The dataset is divided into a few-shot development set, a validation set, and a test set. The few-shot development set includes 5 questions per subject, and the validation set, useful for hyper parameter selection, contains approximately 900 questions, while the test set comprises $10.5\mathrm{K}$ questions [2]. The questions in our benchmark were manually collected by a team of 50 college students (including coauthors) from various disciplines and subjects, drawing from online sources, textbooks, and lecture materials [4].

The annotators are advised to select questions without immediately available answers, such as those with answers in separate documents or at the end of textbooks. This process results in a diverse collection of 13K questions from various sources. The detailed annotation protocol is in Appendix A. Data Quality Control. To further control the quality of our data, we perform two steps of data cleaning. In the first stage, lexical overlap and source URL similarity are employed to identify potential duplicate problems. These suspected duplicates were then reviewed by the authors to identify and eliminate any duplications. The second stage involves distributing the problems among different co-authors for format and typo checking. This step requires authors to ensure adherence to a standardized format, undertaking necessary corrections where deviations are found. In the third and final stage, the authors categorize the problems into four difficulty levels: very easy, easy, medium, and hard. Approximately $10\%$ of the problems, classified as very easy and not aligning with our design criteria due to their simplistic nature, are excluded from the benchmark [3].

The MMMU benchmark introduces four key challenges to multimodal foundation models, as detailed in Figure 1. Among these, we particularly highlight the challenge stemming from the requirement for both expert-level visual perceptual abilities and deliberate reasoning with subject-specific knowledge. This challenge is vividly illustrated through our tasks, which not only demand the processing of various heterogeneous image types but also necessitate a model’s

The MMMU dataset is designed to cover a wide range of disciplines, including Art & Design, Business, Science, Health & Medicine, Humanities & Social Science, and Tech & Engineering. The distribution of questions across these disciplines is shown in the image1, which provides a comprehensive overview of the subjects included in the dataset. The image also highlights the heterogeneous image types used in the questions, such as diagrams, tables, plots, and charts, as well as photographs, chemical structures, paintings, medical images, sheet music, geometric, pathology images, microscopic images, and comics.
